reviewText: I'm a big fan of Willis and D'Onofrio and it would seem after watching this picture that they did Fire with Fire for the gas money. Both of these excellent actors were hardly in the film as the movie revolved around Josh Duhamel's part. And boy did he stink in this. He was barely believable as a fireman, let alone a vengeance filled bad guy in this. If he got kicked around like that in real life, he would have been road kill inside of ten minutes. I was hoping for a smart action film and ended up with mere minutes of Willis, D'Onofrio with a really bad accent (what was that supposed to be anyway) and a really bad tattoo, and a total waste of Rosario Dawson - who is better eye candy than Duhamel. This was a predicable movie plot, a wasted cast and a waste of my time and money. Want better Willis? Go see Looper. Want better D'Onofrio? Go see any of the Law and Order repeats. Want better Duhamel? Don't hold your breath.

For those of you who haven't watched this movie yet, believe me when I tell you that you're missing out on a great crime thriller starring Bruce Willis teaming up with Josh Duhamel. The story will blow you away and Bruce's character as a cop along with josh's character as a vigilante once again gets out the best of them. I don't know why this movie didn't hit the theaters first, it's almost on the top of the chart because of it's storyline. ONCE AGAIN BOYS, YOU'RE ON FIRE!!!

In Long Beach, there is a turf war going on. Firefighter Jeremy Coleman (Josh Duhamel) is a witness to a murder and has been placed in the witness protection program where he falls in love with a US Marshall (Rosario Dawson). Bruce Willis plays local police chief Mike Cella who would like very much to see crime boss David Hagan (Vincent D'Onofrio) go to jail.

While in the program, the bad guys find out where Jeremy is located and threaten to kill everyone Jeremy knows and their family. Jeremy goes vigilante in order to save himself and everyone else. He also gives us overwhelming clues about the ending.

I liked the climax of the film, in spite of the fact I knew it was coming from 30 minutes into the film. The script was overly predictable and the dialogue wasn't moving. Vinnie Jones gives us a brief bad guy, and likewise 50 Cent wasn't on screen that long. I would have liked to have seen more of Willis in the film.

Might work as a 99 cent rental for some people. Not a keeper.

Parental Guide: F-bombs, implied sex scene, no nudity. Torture. Bullet holes in the head.

The other reviewers have already supplied the general plot details, so I'll just add my overall opinion.  As my review title states, there is more talk than action, but the action sequences are good and entertaining.  One sore spot with me is that Bruce Willis was given first billing as the star, yet in the film he is nothing more than a paper pusher office detective who does not see any action.  He contributes very little to the general plot, and ZERO to the few action sequences.  Gosh, the producers could have used a fifth-rate, unknown actor from Iowa at 5% the cost of Willis, and the plot would have moved along just as well.  But I guess they just wanted to capitalize on his famous name, not caring that they were actually deceiving the movie viewers.  Makes me think this macho-man hero is getting too old and can't fight bad guys anymore (just like Steven Siegal).  No more Willis movies for me. This movie was a general disappointment.

"I'm a ghost, I don't exist. I'm gonna find you and I'm gonna kill you. I'm gonna disappear and noone is ever gonna know." After stopping at a convenience store and talking to his owner friend Jeremy Coleman (Duhamel) becomes witness to a double murder. When they decide not to kill him Jeremy is left alone to ID the murderer. Not wanting loose ends Jeremy is now a target and he must now fight for his life to survive and also to take care of the killer the the cops have been trying to get for years. I will start by saying that I am a pretty big Bruce Willis fan but he has been very hit or miss lately. I really liked "Catch .44" but thought "Set-Up" was lame. Also as a disclaimer the quote I used is actually from this movie, not from the movie Taken so don't let that confuse you. The movie itself isn't anything new or amazing but it is actually pretty fast paced and keeps you interested and watching the entire time. The movie when you break it down is just another vigilante type revenge movie but again because it's so fast paced and entertaining you can't stop watching. Also Vincent D'Onofrio gives such a great performance in this that watching for just for him is almost enough to keep you till the end. Overall, this is a fast paced exciting action movie that is the perfect kind to just put in and veg out to. I liked it. I give it a B.

I thoroughly enjoyed Fire With Fire from start to finish. I very much identified with it and felt this could happen to me... or to you. I loved the storyline. If you are a Josh Duhamel fan, you won't be disappointed; he is great eye candy and his acting is consistent with his other roles. I thought many of the other actors were absolutely superb such as Bruce Willis, Rosario Dawson, Vincent D'Onofrio (awesomely scary), Anthony Michael Frederick, Eric Winter, even 50 cent! This is a great movie for date night and both will feel satisfied that it was well worth the money. I recommend to not miss this great action crime thriller!
I loved it!

The fastest way to destroy a movie, is for the screenplay to be absolutely impossible, unrealistic, and to contain scenes and situations which could and would never happen. Such a film is usually finished as soon as a bad enough mistake or discrepancy presents itself. Sometimes if the ending is good and the film is overall entertaining enough, -and if these fatal mistakes I'm referring to are minor enough to be forgiven, the film can be salvaged to some extent in the minds of the viewers. But there comes a point, when even the intellect of the average person, is insulted so much, and the scenes are so unrealistic, that they make the film unwatchable. At that point it has to be turned off, and the time spent watching it to that point, must be considered wasted. Such is the case time and again, with this film. I really wanted to like it. But as soon as one fatal flaw presented itself, I knew the film could not be salvaged. That fatal flaw was when this so-called firefighter hero, that had the foresight to ask his firefighter buddy for his gear back (that belongs to the city), was allowed to keep his personal cell phone when going into the witness protection program. When going into witness protection, the agencies involved have to have as much intelligence about the person being protected as possible (such as their phone, cell number, and all communications with family, friends, etc.). Why? Because otherwise, it can totally destroy the program, waste resources and taxpayer dollars, and endanger the lives of the officers, agents, marshals, and other personnel involved. This is not something they take lightly. There is protocol which is always followed by necessity. Such as for an agent or marshal to never date a protected witness. Such a mistake is a career ending and potentially life threatening move. But in regards to this film, that was just the tip of the iceburg. There was so many inconsistencies and ridiculous scenes, it was totally unwatchable. I had to turn it off.

Sometimes films can be entertaining, but for one reason or another are utterly forgettable. In the case of Fire With Fire, I enjoyed the film, but even a few weeks later, I had a difficult time remembering the plot. This is because once again we have an action film that is completely average in every way possible. It's a common story, with a lot of bullets, f words, and bodies, featuring a cast that was far from superb. Jeremy Coleman (Josh Duhamel) is a firefighter who witness a horrible crime. As a result, Coleman is put into the Witness Protection Program, which according to Hollywood is completely inept. Once found, Coleman and his significant other are forced to go on the run and ultimately decide to take the fight to their pursuers, with mixed results. This film was completely predictable and lacked any originality what so ever. Josh Duhamel stars and while he is a good looking, gigantic man, he's not much of an action star. He's lanky, awkward, and simply doesn't have the moves or personality to be believable as an action star. The Director tries to correct this by surrounding him with veteran action stars like Bruce Willis and Vincent D'Onofrio, but it is still painfully obvious that Duhamel got the role simply to be eye candy, further proven by the amount of times he unnecessarily takes his shirt off. As with all action films, Fire With Fire has it's moments, and Vincent D'Onofrio is always an entertaining villain, but aside from that, this film is good for nothing more than a 90 minute distraction, that you probably won't even remember it a few days later.

My husband and I enjoyed this movie - for what it is.  It's a (or should be) low-budget straight-to-DVD movie.

Josh Duhamel was the protagonist of the film and he played a fairly inept average Joe for about 2/3 of the movie. Then vengeance mode kicked in and he went after the bad guys that dared threaten his girl and his best friends.

Bruce Willis had a very minor role but he was good in it.

So - watching this made for a good movie night with hubby. We both enjoyed the film. And how often does that happen?

Everybody loves a good revenge movie.  This definitely fits the bill.  The movie's hero, a firefighter, is in a store during an execution by an Aryan Crime Lord.  He witnesses the entire thing and is not only able to identify the trigger puller but is willing to testify against the leader.  Federal marshalls put him in witnesses protection but that is eventually compromised.  When the leader starts messing with people close to the hero, the hero gets mad.

Bruce Willis plays a police officer from a small town.  During the entire film he only gets to hurt one guy.  Imagine!  Bruce Willis only hurting, much less killing one guy.

Revenge films are always good for action.  This film doesn't skimp there either.  The good guys remain good while the bad guys get their collective butts kicked.

I enjoyed this movie and wasn't sure the good guy wouldn't lose himself in the chase.  Bruce Willis is a great tough guy and this is a good medium for him. Josh Duhamel shows that he's more than a pretty face and that's all Vegas showed.  He's got some depth to his acting.

Reality: 99.99% of robberies and shootings in black neighborhoods are done by blacks. Most convenience store robberies in both white and black neighborhoods are done by blacks. Many black robbers beat up or shoot the white store workers for no reason.
Fantasy: In the movie, white neo-Nazis with Southern accents terrorize a black owned convenience store in a black neighborhood, shooting the blacks inside for no reason.
It would be like making a movie about slavery in the south, casting whites as the slaves and blacks as the plantation owners. The Japanese tortured and beheaded our WW2 POWs. The Germans treated our POWs well. The Holocaust story turned out to be false wartime propaganda (no gassings, planned exterminations, etc. See CODOH). The Germans never attacked the US. But who is still depicted as the definition of evil 70 years later? Not the Japanese. The anti-white media wants a White bogeyman.

Fire with Fire is a pretty good movie that went straight to DVD that not many people probably heard about.  I really enjoy a good revenge movie, but then again who doesn't?  I recommend this movie because the story is good and it also has a good cast.

The acting is convincing especially the actors who play the lawyer and David Hagan. They make me really hate the characters.

There are some touching scenes. For example the scene relates to Jeremys lover in the first 20 minutes of the movie. The dialogue between them is funny and interesting too.

The action scenes in the first 30 minutes are gripping and suspenseful.

It is outrageously far-fetched with gigantic logical holes. It depicts one ex-fire fighter who successfully fights against the whole group of professional criminals. Yeah right!

It is absolutely predictable from the beginning till the end. I do not know why the criminals who killed cops in the past became so stupid when they confronted the fireman.

In summary, it is worth watching once for fun. Just put your logic to sleep while at it

Brice Willis may be on the DVD jacket, but the star of "Fire with Fire" is Josh Duhamel playing a Los Angeles firefighter Jeremy Coleman in witness protection program. Though he has agreed to testify against a violent mobster David Hagan (Vincent D'Onofrio), Jeremy decides that it is up to him to protect those he loves from the sociopathic Hagan, so he takes some extreme measures, despite the advice from Rosario Dawson's deputy marshal assigned to the case (who is also Jeremy's girlfriend).

"Fire with Fire" is a typical case of straight-to-DVD films, with a few A-list actors in a B movie format. You will notice a wealth of familiar faces like Kevin Dunn, Vinnie Jones and Richard Schiff, all typecast. The story may be as incredible as that of "Collateral Damage," but it is not boring. Actions are not big, but acceptable.

In some low-budget action flicks, "name" actors are there to draw the attention of potential customers, but their roles in the actual films are often miniscule or at best extended cameos. In "Fire with Fire" second-billed Bruce Willis is wasted in a pointless role that is slightly better than the ones he played in "Set Up" and "Catch .44."

Keep your expectation level low, and you may find "Fire with Fire" pretty good. Except the climax scene (based on a questionable idea about fire and firefighter) the film does not have much new to offer, but is still watchable.

If it weren't for the modern props, Fire with Fire could easily have be among the nameless TV movies of the early 1990. Weak script, lazy paycheck cameos from Bruce Willis and 50 Cent, and gratuitous violence. The only redeeming aspect was a notable job by the digital effects team.
Not really much to say other than that this is a good movie (better than a good chunk of what's out there today) and it's worth seeing.

FIRE with FIRE follows a simple, straightforward plot with no huge turnabouts or surprises, even though there are a number of good smaller ones. An interesting entanglement of local cops, firemen, U.S. Marshals, Crips, and white supremacists. Generally good cinematography and acting: Though I've never been a big Bruce Willis fan, his role here fits him well. Good supporting cast and characters, particularly Kevin Dunn as Agent Mullens. Though the film starts out promisingly, it later degenerates into a series of predictabilities, unrealisms, too-easies, and general corninesses, with dialogue that becomes flatter and less realistic as it proceeds. Still, it is very difficult to make a film that's totally clean of such elements, and here, as in many others, they do not come close to being completely ruinous. FIRE with FIRE remains a compelling and riveting show, which is what we all expect, right?

The reviews that I read led me to believe I should avoid this movie.  The plot, ending, and acting were all critiqued unfavourably.  I and my wife found the movie quite enjoyable.  Albeit Bruce Willis does not have the main role, what screen time he did have was well used and his portrayal while not Die Hard quality was accurate and believable.  The ending doesn't spell out the future but I think the conclusion is a happy one.  The final actions aim you in a positive direction where you can be satisfied.  Josh Duhamel came across as a man with little choice but to stand up to the antagonists.  He was inept and conflicted but able to do what needed doing.  A good rental and possible purchase.

Very compelling movie about a fireman who is witness to a set of cold-blooded murders and how he uses his courage and creativity to resolve a dilemma beyond the scope of the criminal justice system.  Our hero is a reluctant hero - albeit a very capable one.  If action, heroism by the street guy and mayhem appeal to you, you should enjoy this movie a lot.  Violence is graphic.

Given the familiar story line of "Fire with Fire" it would have taken a good script just to get it to the level of 'same old same old.' But the script here is stupid to the point it barely reaches above bad.

Here's the scoop. Jeremy Coleman is a fireman in Long Beach. One night he's in a convenience store when Nazi thugs enter and kill the owner and the owner's son because they won't sign over the store lease.  He escapes and can rat on the group's leader (Vince D'Onofrio) but will need to go into protective custody. He agrees and, in the process, falls for his guardian U.S. Marshall (Rosario Dawson) when everything falls apart. Seems D'Onofrio is very resourceful and can track him and her down and kill both. Now our hero firefighter must fight "Fire with Fire." (right)

What a screw-up. This script is dumb beyond the meaning of the word. There are so many lapses in logic and procedure it's difficult to imagine how it ever got a green light. In one scene the marshals leave the hero alone which allows him to escape. Is that S.O.P.? It is also cliche ridden. This scenario has been done before. Many times. You need something really clever to raise it above the fray and that isn't happening here. It's one plodding, dumb scene after another.

Bruce Willis is on hand as a detective out to get D'Onofrio. Why is Bruce doing this part? He looks tired and bored. Does he really need the paycheck? I liked Josh Duhamel in "Transformers" but he just doesn't have the gravity to pull off the hero role here. I'm in love with Rosario Dawson but her role here is nowhere near deep enough for her to rap her talent around. The only standout part for me was D'Onoforio. He was the only character written with any depth. The directing never rose above hack level and all the production values were assembly line.

I knew this wasn't going to be great when I went in but I expected more than this. I expected at least some level of competency, but it just wasn't happening. Don't waste your time.

I think that Bruce Willis just makes movies to make movies these days.  Either he is in some financial trouble or just bored.  Who knows, but he continues to put out these "half hearted" movies. Josh Duhamel stars in this fairly star-studded cast about a California fireman who's taken into witness protection after witnessing a brutal murder in a convenience store. The murderer ends up being a big time white supremacist, played by a scary and superb Vincent D'Onofrio. The opening scene involving a fire was stunningly show, suggesting the film would be a surprise, but as soon as the dialog began I was slightly disappointed. The acting is overall great, but some of the dialog and situations didn't seem natural. Otherwise the film was highly entertaining and great to look at.
Source: criticnic.com 17 November 2012
Disclosure: film sent by Lionsgate

You've seen this flapping turkey before. My biggest complaint is that i bought it instead or renting it via Netflix, cuz this is a one shot deal. Bruce Willis looked like he was on pain killers and never fired a round in this routine good guy on the run from the baddied. I counted three times when the heroes (a fireman who saw murders committed and a nicely-shaped US marshal who falls for the big lug) scuffle and lose their weapons and watch them skid across the smooth floor. Once, maybe, not three times in a movie. Willis could have been replaced with a cardboard cutout and we would have gotten the same visual results. Time for him to retire.
One major plus, the bad guy and his pack of blood-thirsty goons are terrific. They radiate evil and you want them to perish by the sword and slowly. I won't give away the main villain's name but he was in 'Full Metal Jacket' and he was masterful as the head whacko - one problem, not enough mayham by the vicious pack of mad dogs to really make them stand out among mad dog movie killeers - still, not too shabby as bad guys often make the film memorable.
Basic plot line that has been run over by Hollyweird writers scores of times over the decades, tired dialog and lots of mumbling draw this one down two stars and that modern director's flawed fast, lets strain older viewer's eyeballs type camera work knocks this down another half star. A few loose ends, some decent shoot-em ups (without old Bruce bustin' caps) and some vile baddies waiting to die make this one watchable - one time. Anyone want to buy a slightly used DVD in excellent condition? Only viewed once.

Firstly Bruce may be on the cover, but he is not on the screen for too long.  Instead Josh Duhamel is the lead and he does an admirable job of keeping the action looking believable.  This is not for the squeemish as some scenes are hard to watch, so if Reservoir Dogs' ear scene was tough to watch you may want to steer clear of this one.  I am happy I picked it up, but you may want to wait until it is under $10 before buying this one.
Fast paced, great acting and a good story.  Perfect Saturday night movie. I thought that Josh Duhamel & Rosario Dawson are really solid in this movie.

Seems odd to have Bruce Willis and Josh Duhamel yet such a weak script and such an unassuming, joke of a putz for a "bad guy"? He looks more like a janitor or used car salesman than a crime lord! If only they had a bit more quality on the script and a named actor up there with Willis for the "bad guy" this could've been a much better movie. if not for Bruce Willis and Josh Duhamel this wouldn't even be worth watching yet was a real waste of Willis's talents. In the era of bad retreads and just plain unwatchable movies I sat and watched this one which puts it in a certain class I just wish they'd gone the extra mile and a couple extra bucks and made this "great" instead of just "ok".

I like Josh Duhamel. I thought he made the TV series LAS VEGAS interesting when he was there and he certainly fit the bill when he starred in the TRANSFORMER films. Why he hasn't been used more as a leading man I'll never know, but if his output is limited to direct to DVD films then I don't expect him to become the major player he should.

This brings me to FIRE WITH FIRE, the latest direct to DVD flick to highlight the fact it was produced by the same people who brought you RIGHTEOUS KILL and 16 BLOCKS. Come on folks, we really don't care who produces a film because for the most part that's rarely a guarantee that the film will be any good. Fortunately here it turns out that it is.

Duhamel plays Jerry Coleman, a good guy and a fire fighter who witnesses a murder at the local quick mart after stopping in for snacks. The owner and his son are shot and killed in front of Jerry and only through some quick thinking does he escape only to be wounded in the process. Jerry goes to the police and with the sketch they do of the suspect the case pulls in Det. Mike Cella (Bruce Willis). The killer is David Hagan (Vincent D'Onofrio), a white supremacist who killed Cella's partner years ago. Released for that crime, Cella wants desperately to put him behind bars. With Jerry's testimony he can do that.

But things start off bad and eventually get worse. While in a line up to be identified, Hagan lets Jerry know he knows who he is and where he can find him. The D.A. offers Jerry witness protection via the U. S. Marshall Service and he takes the offer. His identity erased from all databases and moved to New Orleans, 8 months go by and the trial date is approaching. But that's not all that's happened.

While being guarded, Jerry has fallen in love with his protector in the Marshall Service, Talia Durham (Rosario Dawson). A big no no in the Service, she plans on moving back to his home town once the case is settled. Too bad Hagan was able to find their location and send in a hit man to kill them both. With Durham wounded, Jerry is able to contact the Marshall Service for help. Though they plan on protecting him more thoroughly this time a phone call from Hagan prompts Jerry to decide to stop running and take the man on on his own terms.

Dropping his agents, Jerry makes his way back home. Knowing that Hagan has been trying to take over turf held by the Crips, Jerry approaches them for a weapon. Once he's armed, he sets out to make sure that he gets Hagan before Hagan can get him.

So the revenge film is set in motion and the side characters offer nice support in this film that actually turns out to be quite well done. The look of the film is completely professional and looks slick. The acting is believable by all involved here. And the story isn't near as thin as a number of main stream major releases seen of late.

Going in I think that most people will know what to expect from this film. Willis has taken on the duties of packing the deck in a number of low budget films in the past few years and my guess is he's trying to pay back helping others on the way up. His name will draw viewers to this film even though he isn't the main focus of the film. But once you get started with this movie you'll find yourself drawn in and watch from beginning to end. It's not a bad movie and you'll get your money's worth with a rental.

Here's The Lowedown on "Fire with Fire" (An Action/Thriller DVD
review)...LIKED IT!!!

Genre: 8 Movie: 7

Checkout "The Lowedown" on Facebook

What's it about?
A fireman takes an unexpected course of action when a man whom he's
been ordered to testify against, after being held up at a local
convenience store, threatens him.

What did I think?
Having low expectations gave big rewards on this one.  I have seen a
few "straight to dvd titles" with Bruce Willis on the cover only to
find that he only has a small part in the movie.  In this movie, he
actually has a primary role and does well with it.  This is a
sleeper pick to put in your players...enjoy!

The reason I deducted one star was because the ending was left open. I hate when a movie leaves the audience with a question, especially if that question pertains to the status of the main characters. It is a fatal flaw that I believe some film makers do not grasp. If I spend 90 minutes or so watching the story unfold, it makes sense that I am interested in something about the story... Since I am interested in the story, it makes further sense that I want to know about the problems the characters are dealing with, how they respond, and what happens to them. Does the cowboy win the battle and the girl and ride off into the sunset? Does ET call home and get through? Does Batman and Robin escape the trap the Joker snared them in?  That is why I will tune in tomorrow night, same Bat time, same Bat channel. So it kindly torques my constitution when I give the writer/director my undivided time to follow the story, care about the characters, cheer them on and pray they are victorious...only to leave the theater wondering what happened to them. I want the story to have a solid ending, a firm conclusion. I want to know what really happened. The story was a little bit weak in that it was highly implausible. I will not drop spoilers. But I will just say that more time should have been spent on the front end, demonstrating that the hero didn't go from Common Joe to Billy Bad Ass overnight with little or no training. Bruce Willis' role is rather limited and more of a supporting nature. That was a let down as I have grown accustomed use to Bruce kicking bad guy rear-end.

Fifty-Cent has a minor supporting role, a cameo really, sporting a 1973 Jim Kelly look, which was kind of comical. I expected him to say: "Man, you come right out of a comic book!"

The Fiver-Star winner in this movie was Bonnie Somerville. I was unfamiliar with her prior to this movie. The Irish Catholic from Flatbush, NY is quite the lass. Her supporting role could have been better defined but her screen appeal made up for the shortcomings in the script.

Rent it?  YES  Own it?  NAH!

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Thank you for reading my review. I hope it was helpful to you.
Rob
